content:
ass="word-wrap-span">WHEN ass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">BrazilIAN soldiers invaded ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay in 1865, after banding together with ass="word-wrap-span">Argentina and ass="word-wrap-span">Uruguay, the country lost a quarter of its territory and as much as 90% of its male population. A century later ass="word-wrap-span">Brazil sent soldiers to a disputed border region, and withdrew only after the two countries agreed to build to build the world’s largest hydroelectric dam, with ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay selling its unused energy to ass="word-wrap-span">Brazil below market value.

ass="word-wrap-span">The dam, named ass="word-wrap-span">Itaipu, is still a sore subject in ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay. ass="word-wrap-span">Last month it emerged that in ass="word-wrap-span">May ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay’s current president, Mario Abdo Benítez, struck a secret deal with ass="word-wrap-span">Brazil, furass="word-wrap-span">Ther reducing ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay’s access to cheap power. ass="word-wrap-span">The resulting outcry has put Mr Abdo Benítez at risk of impeachment. ass="word-wrap-span">The fiasco has underlined ass="word-wrap-span">The importance of a renegotiation of ass="word-wrap-span">The dam’s governing treaty, which expires in 2023.

ass="word-wrap-span">Under the current agreement, which was signed in 1973, each country has the right to half of the roughly 100m MWh produced each year by the dam. ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay, a country of 7m people with little industry, only uses about a quarter of its share, which fulfils 90% of its electricity needs. It sells the rest to ass="word-wrap-span">Brazil, which depends on the dam for 15% of its power. ass="word-wrap-span">But ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay is only paid for the cost of producing the power (including debt repayments on the construction), not the market price of electricity. ass="word-wrap-span">According to the calculations of ass="word-wrap-span">Miguel ass="word-wrap-span">Carter, a political scientist at ass="word-wrap-span">DEMOS, a think tank, had ass="word-wrap-span">Brazil been made to pay market rates, between 1985 and 2018 it would have paid $75.4bn more, or roughly twice ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay’s current annual GDP.

In 2009 ass="word-wrap-span">Brazil’s then president, Luiz Inácio ass="word-wrap-span">Lula da ass="word-wrap-span">Silva, agreed to triple ass="word-wrap-span">Brazil’s annual payment, and to take steps to allow ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay’s state power company, ANDE, to sell directly to private ass="word-wrap-span">Brazilian companies. ass="word-wrap-span">But in ass="word-wrap-span">May’s secret deal, a clause that would have made ass="word-wrap-span">Brazilian companies bid for power was struck out. ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay also agreed to receive around 18% less over the next three years.

ass="word-wrap-span">The agreement became public in July, when ass="word-wrap-span">The head of ANDE, Pedro ass="word-wrap-span">Ferreira, refused to sign it, resigned and accused Mr Abdo Benítez of “high treason”. He and ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay’s minister of foreign relations—who also resigned, along with three oass="word-wrap-span">Ther high-ranking officials—told prosecutors that a “parallel negotiation” was under way to sell power exclusively to a ass="word-wrap-span">Brazilian energy company, Léros. A politician from ass="word-wrap-span">The party of ass="word-wrap-span">Brazil’s populist president, Jair Bolsonaro, travelled to ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay three times on behalf of Léros.

Mr ass="word-wrap-span">Ferreira gave text messages to the ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguayan press purporting to show that an adviser to ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay’s vice-president, Hugo Velázquez, acting with the knowledge of Mr Abdo Benítez, was arranging meetings with Léros and lobbying on behalf of the company. In the messages, the adviser, José Rodríguez, claims that the ass="word-wrap-span">Brazilian politician, ass="word-wrap-span">Alexandre ass="word-wrap-span">Giordano, represents not only Léros, but also Mr Bolsonaro’s family and the ass="word-wrap-span">Brazilian government.

ass="word-wrap-span">The vice-president now denies employing Mr Rodríguez, though he admitted to meeting him to discuss ass="word-wrap-span">The possibility of Léros buying energy from ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay. Mr ass="word-wrap-span">Ferreira has a different story: he says ass="word-wrap-span">The vice-president personass="word-wrap-span">ally introduced Mr Rodríguez as his legal adviser. In one of ass="word-wrap-span">The text messages, Mr Velázquez asks Mr ass="word-wrap-span">Ferreira how negotiations for ass="word-wrap-span">The sale are going.

ass="word-wrap-span">News of ass="word-wrap-span">The secret deal prompted thousands of people to take to ass="word-wrap-span">The streets, calling for Mr Abdo Benítez to be impeached. On ass="word-wrap-span">August 1st Mr Bolsonaro agreed to scrap ass="word-wrap-span">The secret deal. ass="word-wrap-span">Proceedings against Mr Abdo Benítez in ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay’s congress, which had ass="word-wrap-span">The support of some of ass="word-wrap-span">The president’s allies, were dropped. ass="word-wrap-span">But it is too late to stop ass="word-wrap-span">The outcry about ass="word-wrap-span">Energy policy in ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay. In 2023 ass="word-wrap-span">The $2bn loan taken out to build ass="word-wrap-span">The dam will finass="word-wrap-span">ally be paid off. ass="word-wrap-span">The question is what to do ass="word-wrap-span">Then. “2023 is four years away, ass="word-wrap-span">But people on ass="word-wrap-span">The streets are already talking about ass="word-wrap-span">The renegotiation [of ass="word-wrap-span">The deal],” says ass="word-wrap-span">Mercedes Canese, a former vice-minister of ass="word-wrap-span">Mines and ass="word-wrap-span">Energy from Frente Guasú, an opposition party.

ass="word-wrap-span">Many in ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay argue that the country should use the excess power itself. A team at the ass="word-wrap-span">National ass="word-wrap-span">University of Asunción led by ass="word-wrap-span">Gerardo Blanco, an engineering professor, has identified four sectors that could scale up quickly: plastics, cement, glass and wooden furniture.

In recent years, firms have been drawn to ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay’s industrial border zone by low taxes, cheap labour and the dam’s cheap electricity. ass="word-wrap-span">Car companies with factories in ass="word-wrap-span">Brazil have started manufacturing cables in ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay. In Ciudad del Este, just south of the dam, many locals engage in Bitcoin mining, an exceptionass="word-wrap-span">ally power-hungry business. ass="word-wrap-span">Demand from homes and offices is growing quickly, too. ass="word-wrap-span">Within a few decades, ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay’s half of ass="word-wrap-span">Itaipu’s output “will go to air-conditioning,'' says ass="word-wrap-span">Christine Folch, a cultural ass="word-wrap-span">anthropologist from ass="word-wrap-span">Duke ass="word-wrap-span">University who is the author of “Hydropolitics”, a forthcoming book about the dam. By that point, the country will need some other sources of energy.

ass="word-wrap-span">Until ass="word-wrap-span">Then, however, most of ass="word-wrap-span">The power will still be sold to ass="word-wrap-span">Brazil. ass="word-wrap-span">Brazil’s economy is 50 times bigger than that of its lass="word-wrap-span">Andlocked neighbour. ass="word-wrap-span">And ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay is not well equipped to negotiate a better arrangement. ass="word-wrap-span">Whereas Mr Bolsonaro put a trio of military generals in charge of ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Brazilian half of ass="word-wrap-span">Itaipu, ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay doesn’t even have a fully fledged energy ministry. ass="word-wrap-span">The messages published by Mr ass="word-wrap-span">Ferreira between government officials in ass="word-wrap-span">The lead-up to ass="word-wrap-span">The abass="word-wrap-span">Andoned deal show this asymmetry. ass="word-wrap-span">Brazil sets ass="word-wrap-span">The agenda; ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay caves to its every demass="word-wrap-span">And.

ass="word-wrap-span">Public pressure may help change that. On ass="word-wrap-span">August 7th ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay’s government named Mr Blanco, ass="word-wrap-span">The engineering professor, to ass="word-wrap-span">Itaipu’s governing council, in a show of transparency. As it contemplates its strategy for 2023, ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay may look to oass="word-wrap-span">Ther smaller countries’ battles with big neighbours. In ass="word-wrap-span">The 1970s a campaign in ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">United ass="word-wrap-span">States involving letters from ass="word-wrap-span">The actor ass="word-wrap-span">John ass="word-wrap-span">Wayne helped persuade Jimmy ass="word-wrap-span">Carter and ass="word-wrap-span">The US ass="word-wrap-span">Congress to pass a law that returned ass="word-wrap-span">Panama’s canal in 1999. As for ass="word-wrap-span">The businesses best suited to provide ass="word-wrap-span">The investment and know-how to fuel ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay’s industrialisation, ass="word-wrap-span">Paraguay doesn’t have to look far. ass="word-wrap-span">They are right over ass="word-wrap-span">The border in ass="word-wrap-span">Brazil.
